I can play this to a much better degree on my laptop's touchscreen, but touchscreen laptops are relatively new and not many people have them yet. I've given up playing this on my main PC and will only play it on my touchscreen laptop due to the significant frustration level when (trying to) play this with a mouse.The game itself is very cute with a cutout-style art design and some of the levels are very challenging even with a touchscreen. He then gets revenge by cutting all of the trees in the world down. So at the start of each level, Jack grabs his ax and sends an electric shock through the forest. Sending every tree up into the air. As they fall down, you have to draw a line through the logs to slice them in half. It starts off with normal logs, but then L, U, and T shaped logs come into play as well as logs that need to be cut 2 or 3 times. At the end of each level, an animal appears inthe middle of a formation of logs. If you slice the animal, you fail, but if you dont, after each level, all of the animals you collect appear in your cabin. You can click them and they will bounce around. 												I don't mind iOS ports too much, and while I admire the concept Jack Lumber presents (think Fruit Ninja crossed with connect the dots and bullet time), the core gameplay requires a lot of precision and not a lot of room for error, which is a bit of a problem when playing with a mouse. It's easy during the first 3 or 4 levels, but soon after you're required to get through each minichallenge without screwing up, or else your score won't be high enough to advance. Once the game starts introducing conditions to finish the challenge, such as cutting through misshapen logs or fast spinning ones, the game loses its charm quickly. The time window they give is very brief, and the more that is thrown at you, the less you can keep up. There are options to purchase 1 use items that can give you a slight edge, but none that I have found or unlocked so far gives me anything permanent, nor extend the amount of time I have to cut. If I had this for the systems it was designed for I imagine I would love it. The art style is great, the humor solid, and the nuances an interesting touch. However, it was not meant for the PC, and those who are looking for laidback fun like this game promises will quickly become irritated. Don't bother, or at the very least, get it on something with a touchscreen.

												To be perfectly honest I see this more as a simulation game of how life would be like for an emotionally underdeveloped, mentally unstable, orphaned canadian living through the trauma of having his guardian (grandma) killed by a falling - sorry, evil - tree.In short: "ooooooh, granneh!" - the immortal wisdom of Jack Lumber, the lumberjack (I get it!),Pros:- Very charming graphics (and audio!).- Depending on your level of involvement and how much you're interested in putting into the game you can have a very hard time getting plaid sashes or a fairly alright time 'only' working up as many stars as you need just to unlock the final boss battle.- Smooth gameplay that you can regulate the difficulty of further by putting on different beards.- The entire game is pretty quirky and odd which again feeds into the charms of the game.- An appealingly bizzare storyline, although it is only very basic as this is, after all, only a fairly short game. - No animals are supposed to be harmed in this game (if you do, you fail the level). Only evil, evil plants. As a plant hating vegetarian i approve (Please do imagine me seething and foaming at the mouth as hacking and slashing up the disgusting wood logs while laughing manically). I kid. Of course. No. But seriously. Death to plants!- Canadian simulator.- The sassy beaver is sassy.Cons:- The intro to the level tends to get annoying over time with the whole cutscene that you just cannot skip no matter how much you bash your keyboard.- In order to purchase all items in the shops and try all the difficulties with different beards while having the comfort of being able to regulate the game difficulty with different syrups you have to play close to insane amounts of games to earn enough wood (currency),  Loses some appeal to me because of this as you need way too much wood to keep me motivated to earn it.- The noises of the animals tends to get annoying over time.- Somewhat replayable, but not really. I played it twice with a year between. Enough to forget the setup of each level. But the log tosses are always the same and if you replay it too shortly after last finishing (or have a photographic memory) you'll have memorized each log toss for each level.. if you're as anal about getting best possible ranking for each level as i am, anyway.Summary:A very good, charming game with a very calm demeanor to it. Although others may react differently as the tosses are timed I found it soothing rather than stressful and really rather funny. Keep in mind, though, that my humour is beyond ridiculous. For me it was well worth the full price of the game and i enjoyed it enough to wish to support the developers enough to buy cards enough to get a full tier badge. Would've gotten more of them if that didn't mean i'd have craptons of cards in my inventory i can't do anything with.
